description: Lists, Tuples & Basic Sequences, Control Flow in Python, Dictionaries & Sets

singleQuestions.title:
After this code, what is `colors`?
```python
colors = ['red', 'green']
colors.extend(['blue', 'yellow'])
```
singleQuestions.explanation: `.extend()` adds each element of the iterable individually (unlike `.append()`).

singleQuestions.title:
Which removes the first occurrence of 7?
```python
values = [7, 2, 7, 9, 7]
```
singleQuestions.explanation: `.remove(value)` deletes the **first** occurrence of that value. `.pop()` uses index, not value.

singleQuestions.title:
What is printed?
```python
nums = [1, 3, 2, 4]
nums.sort()
print(nums)
```
singleQuestions.explanation: `.sort()` sorts **in place** (modifies the list) and returns `None`. After the call, `nums` is `[1, 2, 3, 4]`.

singleQuestions.title: Which list comprehension creates `[0, 2, 4, 6, 8]`?

answerVariants.value: [x for x in range(10) if x % 2 == 0]

singleQuestions.explanation: All three produce the same result: even numbers from 0 to 8.

singleQuestions.title: What is the result of `lst[-2]` when `lst = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']`?
singleQuestions.explanation: Negative indexing: -1 is last item ('d'), -2 is second-to-last → **'c'**.

singleQuestions.title:
What happens after this code runs?
```python
fruits = ['apple', 'banana']
fruits.append(['cherry', 'date'])
print(len(fruits))
```
singleQuestions.explanation: `.append()` adds a single element (here: a list) → fruits becomes `['apple', 'banana', ['cherry', 'date']]` → length **3**.

singleQuestions.title: Which line correctly unpacks the tuple?
singleQuestions.explanation: Tuple unpacking requires matching number of variables (or using `*` or `_`). Option b correctly unpacks with `_` ignoring the last value.

singleQuestions.title:
Which loop never executes its body?
```python
# Option A
for _ in range(0):
    print(1)

# Option B
i = 5
while i < 5:
    print(2)

# Option C
for i in []:
    print(3)
```
singleQuestions.explanation: range(0) → empty, while 5<5 → false, empty list → empty iterable. All three never run.

singleQuestions.title: Which expression is equivalent to `not (a and b)`?
singleQuestions.explanation: De Morgan's law: `not (A and B)` ⇔ `not A or not B`.
10 > 15 is false → check next condition → 10 > 5 is true → prints **medium**.

singleQuestions.title:
What is printed?
```python
for x in range(6):
    if x == 3:
        continue
    print(x, end='')
```
singleQuestions.explanation: `continue` skips the rest of the loop body when x==3 → 3 is not printed.

singleQuestions.title:
What does this code print?
```python
s = {1, 2, 3}
s.add(2)
print(len(s))
```
singleQuestions.explanation: Sets automatically eliminate duplicates. Adding an existing element does nothing → length remains **3**.

singleQuestions.title: What is the result of `len({'x':10, 'y':20, 'x':30})`?
singleQuestions.explanation: Dictionaries cannot have duplicate keys. Last value wins → `{'x':30, 'y':20}` → length **2**.

singleQuestions.title: Which is the most efficient way to check if a key exists in a dictionary?
singleQuestions.explanation: `in` on a dict directly checks keys and is the fastest & most readable idiom.

singleQuestions.title: Which operation gives elements present in **either** set but not both?
singleQuestions.explanation: `^` is the **symmetric difference** operator → elements in exactly one of the sets.

singleQuestions.title: Which is **not** a valid set operation result?
singleQuestions.explanation: Sets do **not** support `+` for union. Use `|` instead.

singleQuestions.title: What does `d.items()` return in Python 3?
singleQuestions.explanation: `.items()` returns a **dict_items** view — dynamic and memory efficient.

questionGroups.groupTitle: List comprehensions & slicing – choose the correct result

questions.title:
What does this produce?
```python
[x * 2 for x in range(1, 6) if x % 2 == 1]
```
Given `s = 'python'`, what is `s[::2]`?
questions.explanation: Step=2 from beginning → every second character: p,y,t,h,o,n → indices 0,2,4 → **'pto'**

questions.title: Result of `[n for n in range(10) if n > 3 and n < 7]`?
Which creates a new list with squares of even numbers 0–10?

answerVariants.value: [x**2 for x in range(11) if x % 2 == 0]

questionGroups.groupTitle: Choose the correct outcome / best description

questions.title: What is the most Pythonic way to loop over numbers 0 to 9?
questions.explanation: `range(10)` is clean, memory-efficient and idiomatic for this purpose.

questions.title: `if x:` is usually the same as:

answerVariants.value: `if x != 0 and x is not None and x != '' and x != False:`

questions.explanation: `if x:` implicitly calls `bool(x)`. Most accurate match is option c.

questions.title: Which construct lets you skip the rest of the current iteration and move to the next one?
questions.explanation: `continue` jumps immediately to the next iteration.

questions.title: What does `range(5, 0, -1)` generate?
questions.explanation: Starts at 5, decreases by 1 each time, stops **before** 0 → 5 4 3 2 1.
